newsitem.title: JAPAN: Crude prices jump in Asia on second attack on Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Crude prices jump in Asia on second attack on Iraq.

text.p: Crude oil prices in Asia jumped 30 cents on Wednesday after the United States said it launched a second missile attack on Iraq.

The benchmark October futures contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX), trading on the screen-based ACCESS system during Asian hours, jumped to $23.65 per barrel from the price of $23.35 it was at when news of the second missile attack first broke.
A U.S. administration official said the United States launched a second cruise missile attack on Iraq but did not immediately provide details.
The October futures price reached on Wednesday, however, was still well below the $24.25 high for the contract seen on Tuesday after the United States' first missile attack.

The first attack involved 27 cruise missiles fired by U.S. Navy warships and B-52 bombers at military targets in southern Iraq. It was a retaliation for the incursion of Iraqi forces into the northern Kurdish region where the United Nations operates a no-fly zone.
Defence officials said privately that the first missile attack on Iraqi air defence targets in the south of the country had not done the damage expected.

Tsutomu Toichi, director of Institute of Energy Economics (IEE) in Tokyo, said: "I don't think NYMEX light crude will rise as high as $30 unless there is a major escalation in the confrontation. But it could top the high of yesterday."

Meanwhile, the October Brent crude contract, trading on the Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX), rose as high as $22.50 per barrel after the news on Wednesday, up 29 cents from the London close.

One broker said the latest escalation of hostilities could push the October Brent contract to match its day-earlier high of $23.50, which was also the highest for any prompt month Brent contract since the Gulf War of 1991.
But he said he expected traders to be cautious about over-reacting.
"I don't think there will be as much panic today as yesterday," he said.
By late Tokyo morning trade, October NYMEX crude was last traded at $23.44 and October Brent was last traded at $22.31.
